Award.AwardTitle: The Cultural Shaping of Leadership Judgments: The Role of Ideal Affect

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the US population grows more ethnically diverse, so does its workforce. Presently, individuals of non-European American backgrounds comprised approximately 36% of the American workforce, and by 2050, these workers will be responsible for 85% of its growth. There is a striking lack of ethnic diversity, however, among leaders in all sectors of the American economy. For example, although Asian Americans are the most highly represented minority group in academic settings (comprising 6.2% of faculty), and have the highest percentage of college degrees of any ethnic group, they hold only 2.4% of top administrative positions in higher education, compared to African Americans (9.4%) and Latino Americans (3.6%). This disparity, and similar ones observed in business and political settings, have been cited as evidence of a "bamboo ceiling," or limit to career advancement for Asian Americans. What factors might be responsible for the bamboo ceiling and other barriers to advancement for different ethnic minority groups?

Various scholars have argued that these barriers are due to racial discrimination and stereotyping. In the current project, Jeanne Tsai (Stanford University) and colleagues propose that European American employers may unknowingly engage in "affective discrimination," or discrimination based on a cultural mismatch between the emotional ideals ("ideal affect") of European American employers and their ethnic minority employees. Affective discrimination may be less obvious than other types of discrimination because people are often unaware of how their cultures shape their emotions, and because the emotion-based judgments that people make about others often occur quickly, automatically, and outside conscious awareness. In previous work, Tsai and colleagues found that whereas North American cultures value excitement, enthusiasm, and other "high arousal positive" states more, East Asian cultures value calm, peacefulness, and other "low arousal positive" states more. Thus, consistent with their ideals, European American employers may seek to promote excited and enthusiastic leaders, which may inadvertently disadvantage Asian Americans and other employees who value and therefore express other affective states.

The project will examine whether people's ideal affect influences their leadership judgments in different occupational settings (business and engineering) and under varying work conditions (periods of normality vs. periods of crisis), why biases occur (i.e., the underlying psychological mechanisms), and whether people can be taught to account for cultural and individual differences in ideal affect when judging others' potential for leadership. The project uniquely utilizes cross-cultural, experimental, and neuroimaging methods to capture these processes. Findings from this work will advance scientific understanding of how culture shapes the judgments people make about others based on emotional expression, and will advance methods for integrating neural, psychological, and cultural levels of analysis. This work also promises to identify ways of breaking down barriers to advancement for different ethnic groups in the U.S., and to develop methods of teaching members of all groups how to work together harmoniously in an increasingly multicultural society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the US population grows more ethnically diverse, so does its workforce. There is a striking lack of ethnic diversity, however, among leaders in all sectors of the American economy. What are the barriers to advancement for ethnic minority groups? The overall aim of this project was to examine whether cultural differences in ideal affect (i.e., the emotions that people value and ideally want to feel) might serve as one barrier. In previous work, we found that European American culture values excitement, enthusiasm, and other "high arousal positive" states more, and calm, peacefulness, and other "low arousal positive" states less than East Asian cultures do. Consistent with their ideals, European American employers may seek and promote excited and enthusiastic leaders, which may inadvertently disadvantage Asian Americans and other employees who value and express other affective states.

Specifically, the project aimed to: (1) examine whether cultural differences in people’s ideal affect influence their leadership choices in different occupational settings (business, government, research), and under varying work conditions (periods of growth vs. stability vs. crisis), (2) understand why such biases occur (i.e., identify the underlying psychological mechanisms), (3) examine whether teaching people to value different affective states alters their leadership choices, and (4) begin to assess whether people can learn to account for cultural differences in ideal affect when judging others' potential for leadership. To achieve these aims, the work used cross-cultural, experimental, and neuroimaging methods.

To achieve the first aim, we compared the emotional content of the official photos of leaders from different nations, and observed that U.S. leaders were 6.25 times more likely to show excited smiles than Chinese leaders. These findings held for business, government, and academia. In another series of studies, we demonstrated that European Americans are more likely to hire excited (vs. calm) applicants who are similar in qualifications for a customer service internship compared with Hong Kong Chinese. In another study, we asked European Americans and Hong Kong Chinese to read about companies, government agencies, and research labs that were undergoing growth, stability, or crisis, and to choose a leader for each organization among excited, calm, and neutral candidates who were similar in qualifications. Again, occupational setting did not matter: European Americans were more likely to choose excited leaders and were less likely to choose calm leaders than Hong Kong Chinese in business, government, and academia. Work conditions, however, did matter: cultural differences in leadership choice emerged during organizational growth and stability but not during crisis. During crisis, participants showed no preference for excited, calm, or neutral candidates, and this was true across cultures.

To achieve the second aim, we asked European Americans and Hong Kong Chinese to imagine that they were hiring someone for an internship and to choose among excited, calm, and neutral applicants. They rated each applicant along different traits (affiliation, dominance, competence). European Americans rated excited (vs. calm) applicants, regardless of their race or sex, as more affiliative (extraverted, agreeable), which made European Americans more likely to hire the excited (vs. calm) applicant compared with Hong Kong Chinese. Importantly, people’s ideal affect mattered less for judgments of dominance and competence. Furthermore, neuroimaging revealed that these cultural differences in affiliation judgments were related to positive affect and reward processes (but not processes related to negative affect, identity, or visual attention). Thus, compared to Hong Kong Chinese, European Americans experienced excited (vs. calm) applicants as more positive and rewarding, which led them to judge excited (vs. calm) applicants as more affiliative, which in turn led them to hire excited (vs. calm) applicants more.

To achieve our third aim, European Americans, Asian Americans, and Hong Kong Chinese either read a passage about the value of excitement for health and well-being, or one about the value of calm for health and well-being. Afterwards, participants read about companies, government agencies, and research labs that were undergoing growth, stability, or crisis, and were asked to choose a leader for each organization among excited, calm, and neutral candidates. Across cultures, participants who were taught to value excitement more were more likely to choose excited leaders for organizations that were undergoing growth than were participants who were taught to value calm more. These findings suggest that people can be taught to value different affective states, and this can in turn influence their leadership choices.

To achieve our fourth aim, we presented our results to various academic and lay audiences. In addition, our work has received significant attention by various media outlets including Newsweek, The Washington Post, and the World Economic Forum. The responses we have received have been very positive, and include interest in the application of our findings to various organizations. The next step will be to develop and evaluate an intervention that teaches people to take others’ ideal affect into account when judging their potential for leadership.
